member.name: F:Microsoft.Diagnostics.Runtime.Interop.DEBUG_STATUS_FLAGS.INSIDE_WAIT
member.summary: This bit is added in DEBUG_CES_EXECUTION_STATUS notifications when the engines execution status is changing due to operations performed during a wait, such as making synchronous callbacks. If the bit is not set the execution status is changing due to a wait being satisfied.

member.name: F:Microsoft.Diagnostics.Runtime.Interop.DEBUG_STATUS_FLAGS.WAIT_TIMEOUT
member.summary: This bit is added in DEBUG_CES_EXECUTION_STATUS notifications when the engines execution status update is coming after a wait has timed-out. It indicates that the execution status change was not due to an actual event.

member.name: F:Microsoft.Diagnostics.Runtime.Interop.ECreationDisposition.New
member.summary: Creates a new file. The function fails if a specified file exists.

member.name: F:Microsoft.Diagnostics.Runtime.Interop.ECreationDisposition.CreateAlways
member.summary: Creates a new file, always. If a file exists, the function overwrites the file, clears the existing attributes, combines the specified file attributes, and flags with FILE_ATTRIBUTE_ARCHIVE, but does not set the security descriptor that the SECURITY_ATTRIBUTES structure specifies.

member.name: F:Microsoft.Diagnostics.Runtime.Interop.ECreationDisposition.OpenExisting
member.summary: Opens a file. The function fails if the file does not exist.

member.name: F:Microsoft.Diagnostics.Runtime.Interop.ECreationDisposition.OpenAlways
member.summary: Opens a file, always. If a file does not exist, the function creates a file as if dwCreationDisposition is CREATE_NEW.

member.name: F:Microsoft.Diagnostics.Runtime.Interop.ECreationDisposition.TruncateExisting
member.summary: Opens a file and truncates it so that its size is 0 (zero) bytes. The function fails if the file does not exist. The calling process must open the file with the GENERIC_WRITE access right.

member.name: T:Microsoft.Diagnostics.Runtime.ClrHeap
member.summary: A ClrHeap is a abstraction for the whole GC Heap. Subclasses allow you to implement this for a particular kind of heap (whether live,

member.name: M:Microsoft.Diagnostics.Runtime.ClrHeap.GetObjectType(System.UInt64)
member.summary: And the ability to take an address of an object and fetch its type (The type alows further exploration)

member.name: M:Microsoft.Diagnostics.Runtime.ClrHeap.GetExceptionObject(System.UInt64)
member.summary: Returns a wrapper around a System.Exception object (or one of its subclasses).

member.name: M:Microsoft.Diagnostics.Runtime.ClrHeap.GetRuntime
member.summary: Returns the runtime associated with this heap.

member.name: M:Microsoft.Diagnostics.Runtime.ClrHeap.EnumerateRoots
member.summary: Enumerate the roots of the process. (That is, all objects which keep other objects alive.) Equivalent to EnumerateRoots(true).

member.name: M:Microsoft.Diagnostics.Runtime.ClrHeap.GetTypeByIndex(System.Int32)
member.summary: Returns a type by its index.
member.param: The type to get.
member.returns: The ClrType of that index.

member.name: M:Microsoft.Diagnostics.Runtime.ClrHeap.EnumerateRoots(System.Boolean)
member.summary: Enumerate the roots in the process.
member.param: True if we should enumerate static variables. Enumerating with statics can take much longer than enumerating without them. Additionally these will be be "double reported", since all static variables are pinned by handles on the HandleTable (which is also enumerated with EnumerateRoots). You would want to enumerate statics with roots if you care about what exact statics root what objects, but not if you care about performance.

member.name: M:Microsoft.Diagnostics.Runtime.ClrHeap.EnumerateTypes
member.summary: Enumerates all types in the runtime.
member.returns: An enumeration of all types in the target process. May return null if it's unsupported for that version of CLR.

member.name: M:Microsoft.Diagnostics.Runtime.ClrHeap.EnumerateFinalizableObjects
member.summary: Enumerates all finalizable objects on the heap.

member.name: M:Microsoft.Diagnostics.Runtime.ClrHeap.EnumerateBlockingObjects
member.summary: Enumerates all managed locks in the process. That is anything using System.Monitor either explictly or implicitly through "lock (obj)". This is roughly equivalent to combining SOS's !syncblk command with !dumpheap -thinlock.

member.name: M:Microsoft.Diagnostics.Runtime.ClrHeap.EnumerateObjects
member.summary: Enumerates all objects on the heap. This is equivalent to enumerating all segments then walking each object with ClrSegment.FirstObject, ClrSegment.NextObject, but in a simple enumerator for easier use in linq queries.
member.returns: An enumerator for all objects on the heap.

member.name: M:Microsoft.Diagnostics.Runtime.ClrHeap.GetSizeByGen(System.Int32)
member.summary: Get the size by generation 0, 1, 2, 3. The large object heap is Gen 3 here. The sum of all of these should add up to the TotalHeapSize.

member.name: M:Microsoft.Diagnostics.Runtime.ClrHeap.GetGeneration(System.UInt64)
member.summary: Returns the generation of an object.

member.name: M:Microsoft.Diagnostics.Runtime.ClrHeap.GetSegmentByAddress(System.UInt64)
member.summary: Returns the GC segment for the given object.

member.name: M:Microsoft.Diagnostics.Runtime.ClrHeap.IsInHeap(System.UInt64)
member.summary: Returns true if the given address resides somewhere on the managed heap.

member.name: M:Microsoft.Diagnostics.Runtime.ClrHeap.ToString
member.summary: Returns a string representation of this heap, including the size and number of segments.
member.returns: The string representation of this heap.

member.name: M:Microsoft.Diagnostics.Runtime.ClrHeap.ReadMemory(System.UInt64,System.Byte[],System.Int32,System.Int32)
member.summary: Read 'count' bytes from the ClrHeap at 'address' placing it in 'buffer' starting at offset 'offset'

member.name: P:Microsoft.Diagnostics.Runtime.ClrHeap.Segments
member.summary: A heap is has a list of contiguous memory regions called segments. This list is returned in order of of increasing object addresses.

member.name: P:Microsoft.Diagnostics.Runtime.ClrHeap.TypeIndexLimit
member.summary: Returns the max index.

member.name: P:Microsoft.Diagnostics.Runtime.ClrHeap.CanWalkHeap
member.summary: Returns true if the GC heap is in a consistent state for heap enumeration. This will return false if the process was stopped in the middle of a GC, which can cause the GC heap to be unwalkable. Note, you may still attempt to walk the heap if this function returns false, but you will likely only be able to partially walk each segment.

member.name: P:Microsoft.Diagnostics.Runtime.ClrHeap.TotalHeapSize
member.summary: TotalHeapSize is defined as the sum of the length of all segments.

member.name: P:Microsoft.Diagnostics.Runtime.ClrHeap.PointerSize
member.summary: Pointer size of on the machine (4 or 8 bytes).

member.name: T:Microsoft.Diagnostics.Runtime.ClrRoot
member.summary: Represents a root in the target process. A root is the base entry to the GC's mark and sweep algorithm.

member.name: M:Microsoft.Diagnostics.Runtime.ClrRoot.ToString
member.summary: Returns a string representation of this object.
member.returns: A string representation of this object.

member.name: P:Microsoft.Diagnostics.Runtime.ClrRoot.Kind
member.summary: A GC Root also has a Kind, which says if it is a strong or weak root

member.name: P:Microsoft.Diagnostics.Runtime.ClrRoot.Name
member.summary: The name of the root.

member.name: P:Microsoft.Diagnostics.Runtime.ClrRoot.Type
member.summary: The type of the object this root points to. That is, ClrHeap.GetObjectType(ClrRoot.Object).

member.name: P:Microsoft.Diagnostics.Runtime.ClrRoot.Object
member.summary: The object on the GC heap that this root keeps alive.

member.name: P:Microsoft.Diagnostics.Runtime.ClrRoot.Address
member.summary: The address of the root in the target process.

member.name: P:Microsoft.Diagnostics.Runtime.ClrRoot.AppDomain
member.summary: If the root can be identified as belonging to a particular AppDomain this is that AppDomain. It an be null if there is no AppDomain associated with the root.

member.name: P:Microsoft.Diagnostics.Runtime.ClrRoot.Thread
member.summary: If the root has a thread associated with it, this will return that thread.

member.name: P:Microsoft.Diagnostics.Runtime.ClrRoot.IsInterior
member.summary: Returns true if Object is an "interior" pointer. This means that the pointer may actually point inside an object instead of to the start of the object.

member.name: P:Microsoft.Diagnostics.Runtime.ClrRoot.IsPinned
member.summary: Returns true if the root "pins" the object, preventing the GC from relocating it.

member.name: P:Microsoft.Diagnostics.Runtime.ClrRoot.IsPossibleFalsePositive
member.summary: Unfortunately some versions of the APIs we consume do not give us perfect information. If this property is true it means we used a heuristic to find the value, and it might not actually be considered a root by the GC.

member.name: T:Microsoft.Diagnostics.Runtime.BlockingObject
member.summary: Represents a managed lock within the runtime.

member.name: P:Microsoft.Diagnostics.Runtime.BlockingObject.Object
member.summary: The object associated with the lock.

member.name: P:Microsoft.Diagnostics.Runtime.BlockingObject.Taken
member.summary: Whether or not the object is currently locked.

member.name: P:Microsoft.Diagnostics.Runtime.BlockingObject.RecursionCount
member.summary: The recursion count of the lock (only valid if Locked is true).

member.name: P:Microsoft.Diagnostics.Runtime.BlockingObject.Owner
member.summary: The thread which currently owns the lock. This is only valid if Taken is true and only valid if HasSingleOwner is true.

member.name: P:Microsoft.Diagnostics.Runtime.BlockingObject.HasSingleOwner
member.summary: Returns true if this lock has only one owner. Returns false if this lock may have multiple owners (for example, readers on a RW lock).

member.name: P:Microsoft.Diagnostics.Runtime.BlockingObject.Owners
member.summary: Returns the list of owners for this object.

member.name: P:Microsoft.Diagnostics.Runtime.BlockingObject.Waiters
member.summary: Returns the list of threads waiting on this object.

member.name: P:Microsoft.Diagnostics.Runtime.BlockingObject.Reason
member.summary: The reason why it's blocking.

member.name: T:Microsoft.Diagnostics.Runtime.ClrException

member.name: P:Microsoft.Diagnostics.Runtime.ClrException.Type
member.summary: Returns the GCHeapType for this exception object.

member.name: P:Microsoft.Diagnostics.Runtime.ClrException.Message

member.name: P:Microsoft.Diagnostics.Runtime.ClrException.Address

member.name: P:Microsoft.Diagnostics.Runtime.ClrException.Inner

member.name: P:Microsoft.Diagnostics.Runtime.ClrException.HResult

member.name: P:Microsoft.Diagnostics.Runtime.ClrException.StackTrace
member.summary: Returns the StackTrace for this exception. Note that this may be empty or partial depending on the state of the exception in the process. (It may have never been thrown or we may be in the middle of constructing the stackwalk.) This returns an empty list if no stack trace is associated with this exception object.

member.name: T:Microsoft.Diagnostics.Runtime.ClrRuntime
member.summary: Represents a single runtime in a target process or crash dump. This serves as the primary entry point for getting diagnostic information.

member.name: M:Microsoft.Diagnostics.Runtime.ClrRuntime.EnumerateGCThreads
member.summary: Enumerates the OS thread ID of GC threads in the runtime.

member.name: M:Microsoft.Diagnostics.Runtime.ClrRuntime.EnumerateFinalizerQueue
member.summary: Enumerates all objects currently on the finalizer queue. (Not finalizable objects, but objects which have been collected and will be imminently finalized.)

member.name: M:Microsoft.Diagnostics.Runtime.ClrRuntime.ReadVirtual(System.UInt64,System.Byte[],System.Int32,System.Int32@)
member.summary: Read data out of the target process.
member.param: The address to start the read from.
The buffer to write memory to.
How many bytes to read (must be less than/equal to buffer.Length)
The number of bytes actually read out of the process. This will be less than bytes requested if the request falls off the end of an allocation.
member.returns: False if the memory is not readable (free or no read permission), true if *some* memory was read.

member.name: M:Microsoft.Diagnostics.Runtime.ClrRuntime.ReadPointer(System.UInt64,System.UInt64@)
member.summary: Reads a pointer value out of the target process. This function reads only the target's pointer size, so if this is used on an x86 target, only 4 bytes is read and written to val.
member.param: The address to read from.
The value at that address.
member.returns: True if the read was successful, false otherwise.

member.name: M:Microsoft.Diagnostics.Runtime.ClrRuntime.EnumerateHandles
member.summary: Enumerates a list of GC handles currently in the process. Note that this list may be incomplete depending on the state of the process when we attempt to walk the handle table.
member.returns: The list of GC handles in the process, NULL on catastrophic error.

member.name: M:Microsoft.Diagnostics.Runtime.ClrRuntime.GetHeap
member.summary: Gets the GC heap of the process.

member.name: M:Microsoft.Diagnostics.Runtime.ClrRuntime.GetMethodByAddress(System.UInt64)

member.name: M:Microsoft.Diagnostics.Runtime.ClrRuntime.Flush
member.summary: Flushes the dac cache. This function MUST be called any time you expect to call the same function but expect different results. For example, after walking the heap, you need to call Flush before attempting to walk the heap again.

member.name: M:Microsoft.Diagnostics.Runtime.ClrRuntime.EnumerateModules
member.summary: Enumerates all modules in the process.

member.name: P:Microsoft.Diagnostics.Runtime.ClrRuntime.ServerGC

member.name: P:Microsoft.Diagnostics.Runtime.ClrRuntime.HeapCount

member.name: P:Microsoft.Diagnostics.Runtime.ClrRuntime.PointerSize

member.name: P:Microsoft.Diagnostics.Runtime.ClrRuntime.AppDomains

member.name: P:Microsoft.Diagnostics.Runtime.ClrRuntime.Threads

member.summary: Attempts to obtain a ClrType based on the name of the type. Note this is a "best effort" due to the way that the dac handles types. This function will fail for Generics, and types which have never been constructed in the target process. Please be sure to null-check the return value of this function.
member.param: The name of the type. (This would be the EXACT value returned by ClrType.Name.

member.name: T:Microsoft.Diagnostics.Runtime.ClrThread
member.summary: Represents a managed thread in the target process. Note this does not wrap purely native threads in the target process (that is, threads which have never run managed code before).

member.summary: Enumerates the GC references (objects) on the stack.

member.summary: Returns true if this is the finalizer thread.

member.summary: Returns true if the thread is alive in the process, false if this thread was recently terminated.

member.summary: The TEB (thread execution block) address in the process.

member.summary: Returns the managed stack trace of the thread.

member.summary: Returns the exception currently on the thread. Note that this field may be null. Also note that this is basically the "last thrown exception", and may be stale...meaning the thread could be done processing the exception but a crash dump was taken before the current exception was cleared off the field.

member.name: P:Microsoft.Diagnostics.Runtime.ClrThread.IsGC
member.summary: Returns if this thread is a GC thread. If the runtime is using a server GC, then there will be dedicated GC threads, which this will indicate. For a runtime using the workstation GC, this flag will only be true for a thread which is currently running a GC (and the background GC thread).

member.summary: Returns if this thread is the debugger helper thread.

member.name: P:Microsoft.Diagnostics.Runtime.ClrThread.IsThreadpoolGate

member.name: T:Microsoft.Diagnostics.Runtime.ClrType
member.summary: A representation of a type in the target process.

member.name: M:Microsoft.Diagnostics.Runtime.ClrType.GetSize(System.UInt64)
member.summary: GetSize returns the size in bytes for the total overhead of the object 'objRef'.

member.name: M:Microsoft.Diagnostics.Runtime.ClrType.EnumerateRefsOfObject(System.UInt64,System.Action{System.UInt64,System.Int32})
member.summary: EnumeationRefsOfObject will call 'action' once for each object reference inside 'objRef'. 'action' is passed the address of the outgoing refernece as well as an integer that represents the field offset. While often this is the physical offset of the outgoing refernece, abstractly is simply something that can be given to GetFieldForOffset to return the field information for that object reference

member.name: M:Microsoft.Diagnostics.Runtime.ClrType.IsFinalizeSuppressed(System.UInt64)
member.summary: Returns true if the finalization is suppressed for an object. (The user program called System.GC.SupressFinalize. The behavior of this function is undefined if the object itself is not finalizable.

member.name: M:Microsoft.Diagnostics.Runtime.ClrType.GetFieldForOffset(System.Int32,System.Boolean,Microsoft.Diagnostics.Runtime.ClrInstanceField@,System.Int32@)
member.summary: When you enumerate a object, the offset within the object is returned. This offset might represent nested fields (obj.Field1.Field2). GetFieldOffset returns the first of these field (Field1), and 'remaining' offset with the type of Field1 (which must be a struct type). Calling GetFieldForOffset repeatedly until the childFieldOffset is 0 will retrieve the whole chain.
member.returns: true if successful. Will fail if it 'this' is an array type

member.name: M:Microsoft.Diagnostics.Runtime.ClrType.GetFieldByName(System.String)
member.summary: Returns the field given by 'name', case sensitive. Returns NULL if no such field name exists (or on error).

member.name: M:Microsoft.Diagnostics.Runtime.ClrType.GetStaticFieldByName(System.String)
member.summary: Returns the field given by 'name', case sensitive. Returns NULL if no such field name exists (or on error).

member.name: M:Microsoft.Diagnostics.Runtime.ClrType.GetFieldValue(System.UInt64,System.Collections.Generic.ICollection{System.String})
member.summary: Convenience function which dereferences fields. For example, if you wish to dereference m_foo.m_bar.m_baz, you can pass: { "m_foo", "m_bar", "m_baz" } into this function's second parameter to dereference those fields to get the value. Throws Exception if a field you expect does not exist.

member.name: M:Microsoft.Diagnostics.Runtime.ClrType.TryGetFieldValue(System.UInt64,System.Collections.Generic.ICollection{System.String},System.Object@)
member.summary: Same as GetFieldValue but returns true on success, false on failure, and does not throw.

member.name: M:Microsoft.Diagnostics.Runtime.ClrType.IsCCW(System.UInt64)
member.summary: Returns true if the given object is a Com-Callable-Wrapper. This is only supported in v4.5 and later.
member.param: The object to check.
member.returns: True if this is a CCW.

member.name: M:Microsoft.Diagnostics.Runtime.ClrType.GetCCWData(System.UInt64)
member.summary: Returns the CCWData for the given object. Note you may only call this function if IsCCW returns true.
member.returns: The CCWData associated with the object, undefined result of obj is not a CCW.

member.name: M:Microsoft.Diagnostics.Runtime.ClrType.IsRCW(System.UInt64)
member.summary: Returns true if the given object is a Runtime-Callable-Wrapper. This is only supported in v4.5 and later.
member.param: The object to check.
member.returns: True if this is an RCW.

member.name: M:Microsoft.Diagnostics.Runtime.ClrType.GetRCWData(System.UInt64)
member.summary: Returns the RCWData for the given object. Note you may only call this function if IsRCW returns true.

member.name: T:Microsoft.Diagnostics.Runtime.ClrSegment
member.summary: A GCHeapSegment represents a contiguous region of memory that is devoted to the GC heap. Segments. It has a start and end and knows what heap it belongs to. Segments can optional have regions for Gen 0, 1 and 2, and Large properties.

member.name: M:Microsoft.Diagnostics.Runtime.ClrSegment.NextObject(System.UInt64)
member.summary: Given an object on the segment, return the 'next' object in the segment. Returns 0 when there are no more objects. (Or enumeration is not possible)

member.name: M:Microsoft.Diagnostics.Runtime.ClrSegment.EnumerateObjects
member.summary: Enumerates all objects on the segment.

member.name: M:Microsoft.Diagnostics.Runtime.ClrSegment.GetGeneration(System.UInt64)
member.summary: Returns the generation of an object in this segment.
member.param: An object in this segment.
member.returns: The generation of the given object if that object lies in this segment. The return value is undefined if the object does not lie in this segment.

member.name: M:Microsoft.Diagnostics.Runtime.ClrSegment.ToString
member.summary: Returns a string representation of this object.
member.returns: A string representation of this object.

member.name: P:Microsoft.Diagnostics.Runtime.ClrSegment.Start
member.summary: The start address of the segment. All objects in this segment fall within Start <= object < End.

member.name: P:Microsoft.Diagnostics.Runtime.ClrSegment.End
member.summary: The end address of the segment. All objects in this segment fall within Start <= object < End.

member.name: P:Microsoft.Diagnostics.Runtime.ClrSegment.Length
member.summary: The number of bytes in the segment.

member.name: P:Microsoft.Diagnostics.Runtime.ClrSegment.Heap
member.summary: The GC heap associated with this segment. There's only one GCHeap per process, so this is only a convenience method to keep from having to pass the heap along with a segment.

member.name: P:Microsoft.Diagnostics.Runtime.ClrSegment.ProcessorAffinity
member.summary: The processor that this heap is affinitized with. In a workstation GC, there is no processor affinity (and the return value of this property is undefined). In a server GC each segment has a logical processor in the PC associated with it. This property returns that logical processor number (starting at 0).

member.name: P:Microsoft.Diagnostics.Runtime.ClrSegment.Reserved
member.summary: The amount of memory reserved for the segment, but not committed.

member.name: P:Microsoft.Diagnostics.Runtime.ClrSegment.Committed
member.summary: The amount of memory committed for the segment (this may be longer than Length).

member.name: P:Microsoft.Diagnostics.Runtime.ClrSegment.FirstObject
member.summary: If it is possible to move from one object to the 'next' object in the segment. Then FirstObject returns the first object in the heap (or null if it is not possible to walk the heap.

member.name: P:Microsoft.Diagnostics.Runtime.ClrSegment.Large
member.summary: Returns true if this is a segment for the Large Object Heap. False otherwise. Large objects (greater than 85,000 bytes in size), are stored in their own segments and only collected on full (gen 2) collections.

member.name: P:Microsoft.Diagnostics.Runtime.ClrSegment.Ephemeral
member.summary: Returns true if this segment is the ephemeral segment (meaning it contains gen0 and gen1 objects).

member.name: P:Microsoft.Diagnostics.Runtime.ClrSegment.Gen0Start
member.summary: Ephemeral heap sements have geneation 0 and 1 in them. Gen 1 is always above Gen 2 and Gen 0 is above Gen 1. This property tell where Gen 0 start in memory. Note that if this is not an Ephemeral segment, then this will return End (which makes Gen 0 empty for this segment)

member.name: P:Microsoft.Diagnostics.Runtime.ClrSegment.Gen0Length
member.summary: The length of the gen0 portion of this segment.

member.name: P:Microsoft.Diagnostics.Runtime.ClrSegment.Gen1Start
member.summary: The start of the gen1 portion of this segment.

member.name: P:Microsoft.Diagnostics.Runtime.ClrSegment.Gen1Length
member.summary: The length of the gen1 portion of this segment.

member.name: P:Microsoft.Diagnostics.Runtime.ClrSegment.Gen2Start
member.summary: The start of the gen2 portion of this segment.

member.name: P:Microsoft.Diagnostics.Runtime.ClrSegment.Gen2Length
member.summary: The length of the gen2 portion of this segment.

member.name: T:Microsoft.Diagnostics.Runtime.AttachFlag
member.summary: Specifies how to attach to a live process.

member.name: F:Microsoft.Diagnostics.Runtime.AttachFlag.Invasive
member.summary: Performs an invasive debugger attach. Allows the consumer of this API to control the target process through normal IDebug function calls. The process will be paused.

member.name: F:Microsoft.Diagnostics.Runtime.AttachFlag.NonInvasive
member.summary: Performs a non-invasive debugger attach. The process will be paused by this attached (and for the duration of the attach) but the caller cannot control the target process. This is useful when there's already a debugger attached to the process.

member.name: F:Microsoft.Diagnostics.Runtime.AttachFlag.Passive
member.summary: Performs a "passive" attach, meaning no debugger is actually attached to the target process. The process is not paused, so queries for quickly changing data (such as the contents of the GC heap or callstacks) will be highly inconsistent unless the user pauses the process through other means. Useful when attaching with ICorDebug (managed debugger), as you cannot use a non-invasive attach with ICorDebug.

member.summary: If this handle is a RefCount handle, this returns the reference count. RefCount handles with a RefCount > 0 are strong. NOTE: v2 CLR CANNOT determine the RefCount. We always set the RefCount to 1 in a v2 query since a strong RefCount handle is the common case.

member.summary: Set only if the handle type is a DependentHandle. Dependent handles add an extra edge to the object graph. Meaning, this.Object now roots the dependent target, but only if this.Object is alive itself. NOTE: CLRs prior to v4.5 cannot obtain the dependent target. This field will be 0 for any CLR prior to v4.5.

member.name: T:Microsoft.Diagnostics.Runtime.GCSegmentType
member.summary: Types of GC segments.

member.name: F:Microsoft.Diagnostics.Runtime.GCSegmentType.Ephemeral
member.summary: Ephemeral segments are the only segments to contain Gen0 and Gen1 objects. It may also contain Gen2 objects, but not always. Objects are only allocated on the ephemeral segment. There is one ephemeral segment per logical GC heap. It is important to not have too many pinned objects in the ephemeral segment, or you will run into a performance problem where the runtime runs too many GCs.

member.name: F:Microsoft.Diagnostics.Runtime.GCSegmentType.Regular
member.summary: Regular GC segments only contain Gen2 objects.

member.name: F:Microsoft.Diagnostics.Runtime.GCSegmentType.LargeObject
member.summary: The large object heap contains objects greater than a certain threshold. Large object segments are never compacted. Large objects are directly allocated onto LargeObject segments, and all large objects are considered gen2.
